items.title: Ukraine, allies advance $800B economic package at Kyiv talks

featured_image.name: Allied security advisers discuss peace proposals in Ukraine ... - PBS

items.description:
National security advisers from approximately 18 countries convened in Kyiv on Saturday to advance a U.S.-led peace framework for Ukraine, including an $800 billion economic support package designed to sustain the country's recovery and growth over the next decade[1][2][3][4].

The high-level talks, which brought together representatives from Germany, the United Kingdom, France, Italy, Poland, and other European nations, as well as NATO and European Union officials, mark a critical step in efforts to end the nearly four-year war[2][5]. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said all documents under discussion, including those on security guarantees, had been shared with the advisers, allowing work to accelerate[3][4].

items.title: 'I could have been where they are': Aussie teen loses friend in Swiss bar fire
items.description: Yaron Lavy, from Melbourne, says he had planned to join friends at the Le Constellation bar on New Year's Eve but stopped to get water — a decision that may have saved his life.

items.title: Venezuelans living in Australia watch events in home country
items.description: Australia's small but tight-knit community of Venezuelan-born residents is gathering to discuss the unfolding situation in their home country after the US captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro.

items.title: Venezuela court orders VP Rodriguez to assume presidential powers

featured_image.name: Maduro's Inner Circle Appears to Survive U.S. Strikes on Venezuela

items.description:
Venezuela's Supreme Court ordered Vice President Delcy Rodriguez to immediately assume all presidential powers in an acting capacity on Saturday, establishing legal continuity for the government one day after U.S. forces captured President Nicolás Maduro in a dramatic overnight raid[1][2][3].

The Constitutional Chamber of the Supreme Court of Justice issued the order on January 3, directing Rodriguez to take charge of the presidency to guarantee "administrative continuity" and the "defense of the nation" following what the court described as Maduro's forced absence[1]. Rodriguez, 56, stepped into the role Saturday afternoon, hours after the U.S. military operation[2][3].

Under Venezuela's constitution, the executive vice president assumes presidential duties when the president becomes temporarily or permanently unavailable to serve[2][3][4]. Articles 233 and 234 outline the succession process, making Rodriguez's assumption of power the legally prescribed course of action[2][3].

items.title: Venezuela oil exports halt amid U.S. blockade, Maduro capture

featured_image.name: Venezuela's oil exports fall sharply after US tanker seizure as only Chevron ships sail - sources, data

items.description:
Venezuela's oil exports have come to a near standstill as tankers avoid the South American nation amid an escalating U.S. naval blockade and the dramatic capture of President Nicolás Maduro on Saturday. The paralysis threatens to further cripple the economy of a country sitting atop the world's largest proven oil reserves.

Following weeks of mounting pressure, including vessel seizures and sanctions, oil shipments from Venezuela have effectively ceased, with only tankers chartered by Chevron continuing operations under special U.S. authorization. More than 11 million barrels of crude remain stranded on vessels in Venezuelan waters, while the country's storage facilities have filled to capacity, forcing state oil company PDVSA to shut in wells across its main production region[1][2][3].

items.title: Venezuelans across the globe divided over US mission to capture Maduro
items.description: Venezuelan migrants across Latin America and other parts of the world cheered in the streets, supporting the US mission to capture Venezuela's deposed president Nicolás Maduro.

items.title: At least 40 killed in US raid capturing Maduro, Venezuelan official says

featured_image.name: Venezuelan Official Says at Least 40 People Were Killed in ...

items.description:
At least 40 people, including civilians and soldiers, were killed in the U.S. military strikes on Venezuela early Saturday that resulted in the capture of President Nicolás Maduro, according to a senior Venezuelan official cited by The New York Times[1]. Official casualty figures remain pending as Venezuelan authorities continue to assess the toll from the two-hour operation dubbed "Absolute Resolve."

Venezuelan Vice President Delcy Rodríguez confirmed deaths among both civilians and military personnel without providing specific numbers[2][3][4]. "Innocent victims have been mortally wounded and others killed by this criminal terrorist attack," Attorney General Tarek William Saab said in a televised statement[5][6].

items.title: Venezuelan VP rejects Trump claim, demands Maduro release

featured_image.name: Venezuela's Interim Leader Defies Trump and Calls Maduro the ‘Only President'

items.description:
Venezuelan Vice President Delcy Rodríguez publicly rejected President Trump's assertion that she had assumed power as interim president following the U.S. capture of Nicolás Maduro, instead demanding the authoritarian leader's release in a televised address that underscored the immediate obstacles facing Washington's efforts to govern the South American nation[1][2][3].

In a Saturday morning press conference at Mar-a-Lago, Trump claimed that Rodríguez "was just sworn in as president" and had told Secretary of State Marco Rubio she was "essentially willing to do what we think is necessary to make Venezuela great again"[4][5]. Within hours, however, Rodríguez appeared on Venezuelan state television flanked by the country's National Defense Council—including the defense minister, attorney general, and legislative and judicial leaders—to denounce the U.S. military operation as "an aggression, a military aggression unprecedented against the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela"[6][7].

items.title: US makes 'bold' grab for oil as markets brace for Monday
items.description: Oil futures do not trade until Monday, Australian time, and financial market participants are divided over whether there will be a spike or correction in the price of oil in Asian trade.

items.title: US military captures Maduro in Venezuela operation

featured_image.name: The Venezuelan diaspora believes Maduro's removal means regime removal. Not quite yet

items.description:
Venezuelans across the globe erupted in jubilation Saturday after US forces captured President Nicolás Maduro in a predawn military operation, ending his authoritarian rule that prompted one of the world's largest migration crises in recent history.

In the early hours of January 3, the United States launched "Operation Absolute Resolve," a massive strike involving more than 150 aircraft that disabled Venezuela's air defenses and extracted Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, from the presidential compound in Caracas[1][2]. President Donald Trump announced at a Mar-a-Lago press conference that Maduro had been "captured and flown out of the country" and would face drug trafficking charges in New York[1][3].

items.title: UK and France strike ISIS weapons site in Syria

featured_image.name: RAF and French Jets Team Up to Smash ISIS Weapons Den in Syria

items.description:
British and French air forces launched a coordinated strike Saturday evening on a suspected ISIS weapons facility in the mountains north of Palmyra, Syria, marking the latest Western operation to prevent the terror group's resurgence in the region[1][2][3][4][5].

RAF Typhoon FGR4 jets, supported by a Voyager refueling tanker, joined French aircraft in targeting multiple access tunnels leading to an underground site believed to store weapons and explosives[1][3][6][7]. The operation used Paveway IV guided bombs, with initial assessments indicating successful engagement of the target[1][2][8][7]. Britain's Ministry of Defence confirmed all aircraft returned safely and that the remote location was devoid of civilian habitation[1][3][8][7][9].

"This action shows our UK leadership, and determination to stand shoulder to shoulder with our allies, to stamp out any resurgence of Daesh and their dangerous and violent ideologies in the Middle East," British Defence Secretary John Healey said, using an alternative name for ISIS[1][4][5][9].

items.title: 'National crisis': Sports stars call for Bondi federal royal commission
items.description: Ian Thorpe, Jess Fox and Lleyton Hewitt are among more than 60 Australian sports stars joining public calls for a Commonwealth royal commission into the Bondi terror attack.

items.title: Caracas residents hunker down after US captures Maduro

featured_image.name: With the President Gone, Venezuelans Race to Stock Up on Food

items.description:
Hours after US forces captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro in an overnight military strike, the streets of Caracas remained largely deserted Saturday as residents grappled with an uncertain future and Venezuelan officials demanded proof their leader was still alive.

The capital awoke to desolate streets patrolled by security forces following explosions that began around 2 a.m. local time[1][2]. Parts of southern Caracas remained without electricity after strikes targeted the Fuerte Tiuna military base and La Carlota airbase[2][3], while smoke continued billowing from the Port of La Guaira to the north[1][4]. Downtown Caracas smelled of gunpowder, according to CNN reporters[5].

President Donald Trump announced on Truth Social that Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, had been "captured and flown out of the country" following what he called a "large-scale strike"[6][7]. The operation, which Trump said was conducted with US law enforcement, marked the first such American military intervention in Latin America since the 1989 Panama invasion that ousted Manuel Noriega[1][3].

items.title: UN Security Council to meet Monday on U.S. capture of Maduro

featured_image.name: UN chief on Venezuela: US action sets 'dangerous precedent'

items.description:
The United Nations Security Council will convene an emergency session Monday morning to address the U.S. military operation in Venezuela that resulted in the capture of President Nicolás Maduro, following widespread international condemnation and warnings that the strikes set a "dangerous precedent" for global order[1][2][3].

UN Secretary-General António Guterres expressed deep alarm at the overnight events, stating through his spokesperson that "these developments constitute a dangerous precedent" and that he remains "deeply concerned that the rules of international law have not been respected"[1][4][5]. The 15-member Security Council meeting, scheduled for 10 a.m. Monday, was requested by Venezuela and Colombia with support from Russia and China[6][2][3].

items.title: Trump defends skipping Congress briefing on Venezuela raid

featured_image.name: Rubio, Trump Defend Decision Not to Notify Congress of ...

items.description:
President Trump and Secretary of State Marco Rubio defended their decision to bypass congressional notification before an overnight military operation that captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro on Saturday, arguing that advance warning could have jeopardized the mission due to potential leaks from Capitol Hill.

"Congress has a tendency to leak," Trump said during a Saturday press conference at Mar-a-Lago[1][2][3]. "This would not be good. If they leaked...I think maybe it would have been a very different result."

The administration's decision not to brief the so-called "Gang of Eight"—the top congressional leaders and chairs and ranking members of the House and Senate intelligence committees—before the operation has sparked sharp criticism from Democrats and some Republicans who argue it violated the War Powers Act[4][5][6]. The 1973 law requires the president to consult with Congress "in every possible instance" before introducing forces into hostilities or situations where imminent hostilities are likely[3].

items.title: Hindus 'living in fear' after man's public lynching for alleged blasphemy
items.description: Four Hindu men have been killed in Muslim-majority Bangladesh in just over two weeks, and several houses have been burned, leaving the minority community traumatised and fearing for their lives.
